required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Survey Study for Velaglucerase Alfa (VPRIV) in Japan

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this post-marketing survey study is to collect data to determine the safety and efficacy of velaglucerase alfa (VPRIV) in participants with Gaucher disease who are new to therapy or have been switched from another therapeutic agent for Gaucher disease.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs) and Serious Adverse Events (SAE) Following Initiation of Treatment With Velaglucerase Alfa (VPRIV)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: An AE is any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medicinal product, whether or not considered related to the medicinal product.An SAE is any event that results in: death; life-threatening; requires inpatient hospitalisation or results in prolongation of existing hospitalisation; persistent or significant disability/incapacity; a congenital anomaly/birth defect or a medically important event.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Absence/presence of Anti-velaglucerase Alfa Antibodies
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Effect of anti-velaglucerase alfa antibodies (including IgGs) will be performed at the physician's discretion per standard clinical practice. Immunoglobulin E (IgE) isotype-specific antibodies will also be measured when clinically indicated (for example, adverse event, serious adverse event or possible of lack of efficacy).

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Significant Change in Laboratory Assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Clinically significant changes in laboratory assessments will be reported.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Hypersensitivity Reactions
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Hypersensitivity reactions are defined as events of drug allergy, angioedema, anaphylactic reaction, anaphylactic shock, anaphylactoid reaction, anaphylaxis prophylaxis, anaphylaxis treatment, drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms.

primary_outcome.measure: Occurrences of Pregnancies/breastfeeding for Women of Child-bearing Potential
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Pregnancy testing for women of child-bearing potential will be collected throughout the survey.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Hemoglobin Concentration
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Every 12 weeks up to 8 years

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Platelet Count
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Every 12 weeks up to 8 years

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Liver Volume
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Every 24 weeks up to 8 years
primary_outcome.description: Liver volume will be measured at the physician's discretion per standard clinical practice.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Spleen Volume
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Every 24 weeks up to 8 years
primary_outcome.description: Spleen volume will be measured at the physician's discretion per standard clinical practice.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Bone Density
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Every 52 weeks up to 8 years
primary_outcome.description: Bone density will be assessed at the physician's discretion per standard clinical practice.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Infusion-related Reactions (IRRs)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of the study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Infusion-related reactions are defined as reactions occurring up to 24 hours after the start of the infusion.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants with anti-velaglucerase alfa antibodies
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to end of study (8 years)
primary_outcome.description: Anti-velaglucerase alfa antibodies will be assessed.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Gaucher Disease Participants Treated With VPRIV
arm_group.description: Participants with Gaucher disease will be enrolled in this survey, who are in VPRIV treatment-naïve therapy or have been switched from another therapeutic agent for Gaucher disease.

study_pop.textblock: Participants with confirmed Gaucher disease (types 1, 2, or 3) irrespective of any age or gender who are either naïve to treatment or participants that have been treated with another therapeutic agent for Gaucher disease.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female participants with a confirmed diagnosis of Gaucher disease
- Participants who are either naïve to treatment or participants that have been treated with another therapeutic agent for Gaucher disease
- Participants who start VPRIV treatment or transition from VPRIV clinical studies during the enrollment period
Exclusion Criteria:
-

patient_data.ipd_description: Shire provides access to the de-identified individual participant data for eligible studies to aid qualified researchers in addressing legitimate scientific objectives. These IPDs will be provided following approval of a data sharing request, and under the terms of a data sharing agreement.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: IPD from eligible studies will be shared with qualified researchers according to the criteria and process described in the Data Sharing section of the www.shiretrials.com website. For approved requests, the researchers will be provided access to anonymized data (to respect patient privacy in line with applicable laws and regulations) and with information necessary to address the research objectives under the terms of a data sharing agreement.
